formal_accuser.name: Maire of St Nicolas (on verbal instructions from Procureur General de Lorraine)

confession.seduction_date: 6 or 7 years before (after being beaten by Jean Faillon)
confession.seduction_context: Returning from begging in villages of Girardcourt, Fleville, and Manoncourt, near fontaine de paille maille, met devil who knew about her misfortunes and promised to aid her if she believed in him. Gave her money which turned to coal.
sabbat_activities: devil exhorting them to do ill and kill people

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused asked if witness had seen the devil, witness replied yes when she saw accused
daughter's fall and injury; husband prevented accused from taking small pieces of wood
fall and injury a week earlier
testimony.threat_quote: ne debvoir le monstrer aux chirurgiens, car aultrement ilz luy gasteroient le bras

testimony.quarrel_subject: son throwing stones near her house and replying rudely
father distributed pork to poor but there was none left when Mengeotte came
children refused to give accused fruit from garden because father had forbidden them

witnesses.name: Jehannon veuve Francois Rozieres
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, had lived in same house for 3 years

testimony.quarrel_subject: daughter was frightened and sent bread out with her brother instead of going herself
testimony.threat_quote: n'auser aller demander chez Didier Regnauldin devant Quasimodo pour cause de sa fille, mais sy elle pouvoit l'attraper qu'elle le garderoit de trop manger du pain

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: immediately after refusing to give bread personally

witnesses.name: Catherine femme Claudin Thomas dit Badel

testimony.quarrel_subject: conversation about storm and whether accused had been in the cloud causing it
daughter accidentally knocked plate from accused's hands while begging in church

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Court at St Nicolas asks for evidence against accused on instructions from procureur general de Lorraine

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: PG de Lorraine (Maimbourg) asks for question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture with thumbscrews and rack; refused to confess despite extensive torture

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Voluntary confession at midday after torture; confessed to pact with devil named Persin and causing three harms

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Pressed for more adequate confession; retracted earlier confession, claiming it was made in fear of torture

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Denied witchcraft, said confession was based on trial she heard about at Creny

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves further torture with moderation appropriate to her age

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Second torture session; racked but persisted in claiming innocence

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Maimbourg asks that she be banished from St Nicolas and ducal territories for four leagues around

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Change de Nancy recommends that she be renvoyée jusqu'a rappel

timeline.subject: Mengeatte des Woirelz
timeline.details: Court at St Nicolas passes sentence: renvoyée (released), but must leave town on pain of corporal punishment

methods: rack - applied four times over more than an hour, up to three turns (first session)
torture.restrictions: Second torture approved with moderation appropriate to her age

prior_accusations.context: 6 or 7 years before trial, accused her of making his child ill and beat her; she complained to maire Claude Regnauld but matter went no further due to her poverty

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte des Woirelz
notable_quotes.french: que l'on luy faict grandissime tort, et que pour estre laide, vieille et decrepitée, les personnes semblent la craindre, et luy imposer une charge d'injure sy ignominieuse
notable_quotes.english: that they do her a great wrong, and that because she is ugly, old and decrepit, people seem to fear her and impose on her such an ignominious charge
notable_quotes.context: Interrogation response about why she was suspected of witchcraft

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte des Woirelz
notable_quotes.french: pour n'avoir aulcung moyen, non pas seulement pour manger a demy son saoul, tant s'en fault pour poursuyvre en proces, seroit este contraincte le tout en la misericorde dieu, en supportant par contraincte patiemment le tort qu'en cela luy at este faict
notable_quotes.english: for having no means, not even enough to eat half her fill, much less to pursue legal proceedings, she was constrained to leave it all in God's mercy, patiently enduring the wrong that was done to her
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she did not pursue legal action after being beaten by Jean Faillon

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte des Woirelz
notable_quotes.french: qu'ennuyée de la prison, et des tourmens de la question, joinct l'apprehension de meschant bruict, que faulsement on luy donne par ville, choisit plustost mourir, que vivre en telle angoisse
notable_quotes.english: that weary of prison and the torments of torture, together with the fear of the evil reputation falsely given her in the town, she chose rather to die than to live in such anguish
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she made false voluntary confession after torture

notable_quotes.speaker: Cathnion femme Jean Cordier
notable_quotes.french: avoir juré de ne plus penser personne, toutesfois luy enseigneroit pour ce coup quelque chose
notable_quotes.english: having sworn not to heal anyone anymore, nevertheless she would teach her something this time
notable_quotes.context: Accused's response when asked to suggest remedy for sick child

notable_quotes.speaker: Cathnion femme Jean Cordier
notable_quotes.french: Mais voulant la contraindre, commenca icelle a crier, qui fut la cause, qu'elle la laissa aller et croit que sy doucement elle l'eut requis et prié de ce faire, et donné a boire, qu'elle eut fait debvoir de soulager ledit son marit
notable_quotes.english: But wanting to constrain her, she began to cry out, which was the reason she let her go, and believes that if she had gently requested and begged her to do it, and given her drink, she would have done her duty to relieve her husband
notable_quotes.context: Witness's belief that accused would have healed if asked nicely rather than demanded

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeanne femme Claudon Housel
notable_quotes.french: les vieilles gens comme elle ont coustumierement cognoissance de plusieurs choses
notable_quotes.english: old people like her customarily have knowledge of many things
notable_quotes.context: Asking accused to help her sick daughter

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeanne femme Claudon Housel (reporting accused)
notable_quotes.french: quand on veult enseigner quelque chose aux gens, l'on en at mauvaise opinion
notable_quotes.english: when one wants to teach something to people, one gets a bad opinion for it
notable_quotes.context: Accused's comment about helping people with remedies

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbe femme Michel Manouvrier
notable_quotes.french: Tante Mongeatte, l'on ne dira pas que fussiez hier en la nuée, car je vous vis hier par tout le jour
notable_quotes.english: Aunt Mongeatte, they cannot say you were yesterday in the cloud, for I saw you all day yesterday
notable_quotes.context: Comment after damaging storm, suggesting accused could not have caused it

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudin Thomas (Barbe's husband)
notable_quotes.french: Peult estre qu'elle n'y a pas este appellée
notable_quotes.english: Perhaps she was not summoned to it
notable_quotes.context: Husband's response suggesting accused might not have been called to cause the storm

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine femme Claudin Thomas
notable_quotes.french: de se bien garder de meffaire a aulcung des siens aultrement elle l'estrangleroit de ses deux mains
notable_quotes.english: to take care not to harm any of hers, otherwise she would strangle her with her two hands
notable_quotes.context: Witness's threat to accused after child's illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicole femme Lienard Remuald
notable_quotes.english: Go, go, you will get out of it
notable_quotes.context: Threat allegedly made by accused to child who replied rudely

notable_quotes.speaker: Judges to Mengeatte
notable_quotes.french: que tout le monde la charge de sorcelerie desia des long temps, et que jamais l'on ne voit de la fumée, que le feu ne soit proche
notable_quotes.english: that everyone has accused her of witchcraft for a long time, and one never sees smoke without fire being near
notable_quotes.context: Judges pressuring her during torture interrogation

relationships.evidence_text: first husband, fossier, married for 11 years, had 7 children who all died
Catherine femme Claudin Thomas dit Badel

relationships.person1: Catherine femme Claudin Thomas dit Badel

relationships.evidence_text: Had long kept company with her, and lived in same house for 3 years

economic_context.details: Nicolas d'Acraigne prevented accused from taking small pieces of loose wood from barn. Multiple witnesses describe accused as living in extreme poverty, begging for survival. She described herself as having 'no means, not even enough to eat half her fill' and unable to pursue legal action when beaten.

harms_catalog.harm_description: whirlwind and dizziness (tourbillon et estourdissement) lasting about 15 minutes, followed by apparition of accused by apple tree
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: gave alms to accused according to her petit moyen (small means)
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: immediately after giving alms and entering garden

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child of Cathnion femme Jean Cordier
harms_catalog.harm_description: strange illness, body all red up to chest, turned all black after treatment, pain ceased temporarily, recovered briefly but died 3 months later
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft, though accused provided healing remedy

harms_catalog.victim_name: Husband of Cathnion femme Jean Cordier
harms_catalog.method_alleged: accused sat outside house spinning, refused to heal when demanded

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell and hurt her arm after exchange with accused
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Nicole said she wanted to make a jump for the one she loved most; accused replied 'mord ung chardon aux dents' (bite a thistle in your teeth)

harms_catalog.harm_description: became so ill while fetching animals that he had to be brought back on a cart; died insisting she had bewitched him to death
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: prevented her from taking small pieces of wood while unloading wood in barn next to her house
child throwing stones near her house, told him off, he replied rudely, she said 'Va va tu t'en sortiras' (go, go, you will get out of it)
father distributed pork to poor but there was none left when Mengeotte came; also daughter knocked accused's begging plate in church

harms_catalog.harm_description: met a 'fantosme' (ghost) with face covered by white sheet that tried to drag him up chimney; child covered with soot and remained unwell afterwards
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Bastien and sister met accused on way back from garden with fruit; she asked for some, they refused saying father had forbidden them, she said they were 'bien ingratz' (very ungrateful)

harms_catalog.harm_description: kept swelling up for 3 hours until she vomited something like poison and recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: daughter was frightened of accused and sent bread out with her brother instead of going herself

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child of Catherine femme Claudin Thomas dit Badel
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: conversation after storm where Barbe said accused was seen all day so couldn't have been in the cloud causing storm, but husband added 'perhaps she wasn't summoned to it' which angered accused

material_culture.context: Used in remedy to make 'estuve' to bathe sick child; also used in 'creme lexine'
Part of remedy for injured arm
Part of remedy for injured arm
Mentioned as part of remedy for injured arm (though accused denied including it)
Given as alms; sought from suspected witch's house as counter-magic
Sought from suspected witch's house as counter-magic
Sought from suspected witch's house as counter-magic
Accused was holding while begging in church; accidentally knocked from her hands
Accused was sewing it up when visited
Offered as payment for healing services
Accused prevented from taking loose pieces; precipitated fatal quarrel with Nicolas d'Acraigne
Devil allegedly gave her money which turned to coal
Devil allegedly gave her powder in a box to throw on people
Devil allegedly gave her grease in a box
Father killed pigs and distributed meat among poor
Nicolas d'Acraigne so ill he had to be brought back on cart

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused and most witnesses
Accused worked tending children for le petit Thomas (2 years)
Accused worked in service with miller (18 months)
Accused worked with barber Jean Conrard (5 years)
Accused worked for messire Barthelemin pretre, brother of maire of Besanges (2 years)
Accused worked for Barbelin Chacton (2 years); plague occurred there
Village where accused was begging when she allegedly met devil
Village where accused was begging when she allegedly met devil
Village where accused was begging when she allegedly met devil
Location where accused allegedly met devil and where sabbat took place

spatial_references.place_name: garden of Nicole femme Lienard Remuald
spatial_references.context: Location where witness experienced dizziness and saw apparition of accused by apple tree
Next to accused's house; where Nicolas d'Acraigne was unloading wood
Accused claimed to have heard about witch trial there which she used as basis for false confession
Where accused begged; where her plate was knocked
Where Nicole met Mengeatte and exchange occurred
Husband of Anne was away in woods

weather_events: damaging storm around St Jean previous year (1583)
economic_hardship_indicators: accused described as living in extreme poverty
accused unable to pursue legal action due to poverty
accused lived with two poor but honest husbands
accused's 'necessité et indigence' known to everyone
accused described as 'vieille et caducque' (old and decrepit)
accused said she didn't have enough to eat half her fill
religious_calendar_references: dimanche gros (Fat Sunday, Sunday before Lent)
Quasimodo (Low Sunday, first Sunday after Easter)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Faillon beat accused 6 or 7 years before, accusing her of making his child ill
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Accused complained to maire Claude Regnauld but matter went no further due to her poverty

legal_context.redress_outcome: Matter went no further due to her poverty; unable to pursue legal proceedings
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Imprisoned from July 2, 1584; devil allegedly appeared to her in prison on night of July 23-24

change_de_nancy.modification_details: First approved torture on July 23; second torture approved August 6 with moderation appropriate to her age; final recommendation August 22 that she be renvoyée jusqu'a rappel (released until recalled)

hearsay_chains.content: accused had told other women not to dare ask at Didier Regnauldin's house before Quasimodo because of his daughter, but if she could catch her she would keep her from eating too much bread
showed neighbors sick child with strange illness
advised to seek bread, salt, and ashes from house of person suspected (l'Esmoulleur)

hearsay_chains.reporter: Catherine femme Claudin Thomas dit Badel
hearsay_chains.content: Barbe told accused about confrerie of St Eloy asking for them

emotional_state_notes: obstinately refused to confess under extensive torture
became very weak during torture and was hardly able to speak
confessed voluntarily after torture but later retracted
said she chose death rather than live in anguish of prison and reputation

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: challenged version of conversation about barber; said Nicole told her that her barber Cesar Dieudonné was ill, to which she replied 'qu'elle avoit bien loysir d'aller au barbier pour sy peu de chose'
said remedy she advised was one previously suggested for Jeanne's husband by Didier de Rome
witness Mongeatte femme Jean Recouvreur was found so 'variable et incertaine' (variable and uncertain) that she was dismissed - she was the one favourable witness

third_parties.name: la Nigade (Nicole Nigade)
third_parties.context: Already executed witch; allegedly healed husband of Cathnion and son of Jean Faillon; accused said she only kept company with her when begging; witness suggested collusion; accused denied la Nigade taught her remedies

third_parties.name: Mongeatte Gatade
third_parties.context: Previously punished/executed witch; accused said she only kept company with her when begging in town or church

third_parties.name: l'Esmoulleur of St Nicolas
third_parties.context: Another reputed witch; witness sought bread and salt from his house as counter-magic. Jehannon veuve Francois Rozieres suspected him rather than accused (called 'la moulerasse')

third_parties.name: Mongenat Boulengier
third_parties.context: Owned barn next to accused's house where Nicolas d'Acraigne was unloading wood

third_parties.name: Agnes
third_parties.context: One surviving daughter of accused from second marriage with Regnaud Tixerand

third_parties.name: Jehanne la Sarpe
third_parties.context: Widow who told accused about illness of Didier Regnauldin's daughter and that accused was suspected

third_parties.name: Didier de Rome
third_parties.context: Accused said remedy she advised was one previously suggested by Didier de Rome for Claudon Housel's husband

third_parties.name: Jean Conrard
third_parties.context: Barber at Vic where accused worked for 5 years

third_parties.name: messire Barthelemin
third_parties.context: Priest, brother of maire of Besanges, at Arracourt where accused worked 2 years

third_parties.name: Barbelin Chacton
third_parties.context: Employer at Varangeville where accused worked 2 years before plague

third_parties.name: le petit Thomas
third_parties.context: Employer at Chambrey where accused tended children for 2 years

third_parties.name: Mongeatte femme Jean Ripaille
third_parties.context: Told Bastienne femme Didier Regnaudin what accused had said about her daughter

third_parties.name: Pierrat Gorgelat's wife
third_parties.context: Advised Jehannon veuve Francoys Rozieres to seek bread, salt, and ashes from suspected person's house

third_parties.name: daughter of la Saracquée
third_parties.context: Barbe substituted bread from her when she couldn't get bread from accused's house

third_parties.name: Colin Bourlier
third_parties.context: Master whose apprentice accused allegedly made ill after refusing bread from wedding feast of master's daughter

third_parties.name: woman of Creny
third_parties.context: Accused claimed she made up confession based on what this woman told her about trial at Creny

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a remarkably detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony and unusual outcome. Key uncertainties: (1) Economic status assessed as 'destitute' based on repeated references to extreme poverty, begging, inability to eat adequately, and inability to pursue legal action - this seems clear; (2) Practiced healing assessed as 'true' based on multiple witnesses seeking her remedies and her knowledge of herbal cures, though she claimed to have sworn off healing; (3) The trial is notable for accused's resistance to torture (withstood extensive torture twice without confession), her retraction of voluntary confession, and ultimate release - very unusual outcome for this period; (4) One favorable witness (Mongeatte femme Jean Recouvreur, witness 15) was dismissed as 'variable et incertaine'; (5) Accused's claim that confession was false, based on hearing about trial at Creny, and made because she preferred death to continued imprisonment; (6) Change de Nancy ultimately recommended release (renvoyée jusqu'a rappel) which local court followed, though she was ordered to leave town; (7) Multiple references to other executed or suspected witches (la Nigade, Mongeatte Gatade, l'Esmoulleur); (8) Strong pattern of quarrels over charity/alms followed by harm - typical witchcraft accusation pattern in context of poverty.
